title: Stop Doing Hard Cycling Intervals at the Wrong Intensities

transcript.full_text: FTP this and FTP bat I'm starting to think we should replace FTP with WTF where's the fun in this video we will explore how to put the fun back into your harder interval sessions as well as making them more productive FTP has become a buzzword among cyclists sure power meters can be fun but a strong focus on Power and FTP can easily take some of the enjoyment out of your rides be careful because it's also easy to stop enjoying the scenery and spend your rides fixated on your bike computer additionally FTP has a much more limited training value than you may realize look at it this way FTP is only a test it's a test that gives us a sign of aerobic progress and performance one of the positives of FTP monitoring is that it can provide ideas as to what training and Life Changes may or may not be working for you however for prescribing training intensities FTP is only Optimum for a limited set of workouts as you likely know most of your training should be easy and a small amount of it hard I agree with science that heart rate is best for determining the intensity of your easy workouts in the rest of this video I will show that percent of FTP is not ideal for hard efforts either using a power meter to set your easy and hard training intensities requires a little more work every human has two primary Energy Systems aerobic and anaerobic easy rides use your aerobic Energy System and strength work is almost all anaerobic I will use the term AWC which stands for anaerobic work capacity FTP represents your big aerobic gas tank and AWC is the small one the two tanks are related but that relationship can be very different for two different cyclists hard cycling VO2 max intervals for example are a mix of both systems but are limited completely by your anaerobic gas tank so if you want to train at your Optimum intensity levels for your hard intervals such as VO2 max or hit these intensities and duration should be based on your AWC not your FTP sounds complicated right one simple solution is to train by feel sure you have a training plan or a workout that provides you specific details on how you should do your intervals I suggest you follow your plan but adjust your intensities based on how hard it feels or your perceived exertion the workout should be challenging but not so intense that you get exhausted save exhaustion for your fun days races or fast group rides are ideal most top coaches agree that pushing the failure or over exerting yourself on a weekly basis is unnecessary and can actually hinder your progress by requiring excessive recovery time during your workout pay attention to your body's signals and adjust your intervals as needed to find the right balance between comfort and challenge to improve your focus and Reliance on feel consider covering your bike computer from time to time if you are enjoying this video please click like and consider subscribing also consider trading in your old FTP for your new WTF metric to learn more about designing AWS based workouts check out our video description below thanks for watching
